answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
I am a big proponent of using Excel for this sort of thing.  It does require a few tricks not typically employed by the average user, but they can be learned rather easily.  My jurisdiction, Cartersville, GA, has developed a quite complex dashboard in Excel which I'm glad to share if you are interested in seeing an example of what's possible.  The major flaw which I've found so far is that you can't really post interactive workbooks (using controls, drop down menus, etc) to the web.  You can, however, post the original xls file or a printout in pdf format.  Let me know if you'd like more information.
Sincerely,
Tom

answers.author: Alan Shorthouse
answers.text:
We (Olathe, KS) recently began implementation of MFR (Managing for Results) from Weidner, Inc. Olathe has tried a number of solutions and we believe MFR will give us the horsepower to meet our objectives, can be easily understood by users, and is not cost prohibitive to implement and manage. What I like so far is functionality to link measures and dashboards with organizational goals and department objectives. We are still in the implementation stages but so far so good.
